item.title: Graph Data Mining
item.description:
Graph Data Mining (GDM)

Promotion: ING2 SCIA (20 students) Year: 2022-2023 Institution: EPITA Lyon
Hours: 3h CM, 6h TP Responsibilities: Created a lecture and practical session, supervised projects.
Description: Covered community detection and pattern discovery in graphs. Students participated in a one-day hackathon.

item.title: Data Mining
item.description:
“Data Mining” (INF2355M)

Promotion: M2 Data Science (60 students in TD & TP)
Year: 2021-2022 Institution: Univ. Lyon 1 DÃ©partement d’Informatique
Hours: 8h TD, 6h TP
Responsibilities: Designed a project combining TD and TP.
Description: Students worked in groups to develop a data mining tool, using an academic paper and Git repository to create tutorials and summaries for future research applications.

item.title: Knowledge Discovery in Data
item.description:
“DÃ©couverte de connaissances dans les donnÃ©es” (INF2418M)

Promotion: M2 Information Technologies and Web (TIW) & M2 Bioinformatics (50 students)
Year: 2021-2022 Institution: Univ. Lyon 1 DÃ©partement d’Informatique
Hours: 2h CM, 2h TP
Responsibilities: Created and delivered lectures and practical sessions.
Description: The lecture introduced machine learning, while the practical session was a tutorial on Natural Language Processing (NLP). Used interactive tools like Wooclap for in-class engagement.

item.title: Psychophysiology of Perception
item.description:
“Psychophysiologie de la perception” (BIO2363M)

Promotion: M2 Neurophysiology of Perception and Sensory Evaluation (20 students) Year: 2020-2021
Institution: Univ. Lyon 1 UFR Biosciences
Hours: 2h CM
Responsibilities: Created and delivered the course (online).
Description: Introduction to data science applied to neurophysiology. Students completed a survey before and after the course to assess their perception of data science and its applications in their field. The shift in responses was encouraging.

item.title: Tracking Olfactory Disorders as Early COVID-19 Indicators
item.description:
Role: data analysis

Collaborators: This study was conducted under the international collaboration of the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research (GCCR), which includes researchers from multiple institutions such as UniversitÃ© CÃ´te dâ€™Azur, University of Florence, Yale University, University of California Irvine and The Pennsylvania State University.

Scientific Objectives

During the COVID-19 pandemic, the loss of smell emerged as a key symptom of infection. Our research focused on:

  • Investigating the link between self-reported olfactory dysfunction and hospital overload.
  • Evaluating whether sudden smell and taste loss could serve as early markers of COVID-19 spread.
  • Analyzing the effectiveness of government measures by tracking smell and taste disorder trends before and after lockdowns.

Challenges

  • Crowdsourced Data Quality: Ensuring the reliability of self-reported symptoms across diverse populations required careful validation and filtering of survey responses.
  • Government Policy Variability: Comparing the impact of lockdowns and public health measures on olfactory disorder trends involved addressing significant differences in policy enforcement and healthcare infrastructure.

Contributions

  • Demonstrated that self-reported smell and taste changes correlated more strongly with hospital admissions than official government indicators.
  • Showed that an increase in smell loss reports preceded peaks in COVID-19 cases, suggesting its utility as an early pandemic marker.
  • Highlighted that stricter lockdown measures resulted in faster declines in reported olfactory dysfunction, indicating their effectiveness.
  • Developed R scripts for data analysis, available on OSF (Open Science Framework).

Dissemination and Publications
